<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|> A manager is investigating the times taken by employees to complete a particular task as a result of the introduction of new technology. He claims that the mean time taken to complete the task is reduced by more than 0.4 minutes. He chooses a random sample of 10 employees. The times taken, in minutes, before and after the introduction of the new technology are recorded in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 149, 910, 257]]<|/det|>
EmployeeABCDEFGHIJ
Time before new technology10.29.812.411.610.811.214.610.612.311.0
Time after new technology9.68.512.410.910.210.612.810.812.510.6
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 144, 381]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 740, 381]]<|/det|> Test at the \(10\%\) significance level whether the manager's claim is justified. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 363, 920, 381]]<|/det|> [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 740, 91]]<|/det|>
The probability generating function, \(\mathrm{G}_Y(t)\), of the random variable \(Y\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 101, 675, 122]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{G}_Y(t) = 0.04 + 0.2t + 0.37t^2 + 0.3t^3 + 0.09t^4.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 255, 152]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{Var}(Y)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 843, 89]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Y\) is the sum of two independent observations of the random variable \(X.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 148, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 831, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the probability generating function of \(X,\) giving your answer as a polynomial in \(t.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 724, 91]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 97, 656, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k x(4 - x) & 0\leqslant x< 2,\\ k(6 - x) & 2\leqslant x\leqslant 6,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 288, 181]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 194, 144, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 299, 212]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{3}{40}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 918, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 144, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 437, 399]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{E}(X) = 2.5\), find \(\mathrm{Var}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 153]]<|/det|> A scientist is investigating the numbers of a particular type of butterfly in a certain region. He claims that the numbers of these butterflies found per square metre can be modelled by a Poisson distribution with mean 2.5. He takes a random sample of 120 areas, each of one square metre, and counts the number of these butterflies in each of these areas. The following table shows the observed frequencies together with some of the expected frequencies using the scientist's Poisson distribution. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 165, 902, 260]]<|/det|>
Number per square metre0123456â‰¥ 7
Observed frequency1220363213610
Expected frequency9.8524.6330.7825.65\(p\)8.023.34\(q\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 146, 290]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 584, 291]]<|/det|> Find the values of \(p\) and \(q\), correct to 2 decimal places. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 186, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 609, 850, 628]]<|/det|> Carry out a goodness of fit test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, to test the scientist's claim. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 610, 920, 628]]<|/det|> [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 892, 89]]<|/det|>
Raman claims that the population mean height of male giraffes in the region is less than 5.9 metres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level whether this sample provides sufficient evidence to support Raman's claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 153]]<|/det|> A teacher at a large college gave a mathematical puzzle to all the students. The median time taken by a random sample of 24 students to complete the puzzle was 18.0 minutes. The students were then given practice in solving puzzles. Two weeks later, the students were given another mathematical puzzle of the same type as the first. The times, in minutes, taken by the random sample of 24 students to complete this puzzle are as follows. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 165, 875, 237]]<|/det|>
18.217.516.415.120.526.519.223.2
17.918.825.819.917.716.217.316.6
17.120.120.312.616.021.422.718.4
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 920, 286]]<|/det|> The teacher claims that the practice has not made any difference to the average time taken to complete a puzzle of this type. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 297, 920, 332]]<|/det|> Carry out a Wilcoxon signed-rank test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, to test whether there is sufficient evidence to reject the teacher's claim.
